awd_titl_txt: Supporting Students' Science Content Knowledge through Project-Based Inquiry
awd_abstract_narration:
The Project-Based Inquiry (PBI) Global initiative will address STEM learning through classroom implementation at two project partner schools in North Carolina, one urban and the other rural, with culturally diverse student populations. Both are innovative public high schools implementing the Early College High School model, preparing diverse students from populations underrepresented in STEM fields for college success. Because of the synergistic interaction of theory and practice, the project will produce substantial advances in  the development of improved inquiry-based learning materials and research on the impact of these materials on students and teachers. The project offers high school students the opportunity to be immersed in science content through engaging in globally-relevant learner-centered activities. The following three research questions will be addressed: 1) How does inquiry through the PBI Global process support student science content knowledge? 2) How can students' motivation and engagement be characterized after participating in the PBI Global process? 3) To what degree do teachers' attitudes toward inquiry-based pedagogies change as a result of PBI Global professional development?

Project-Based Inquiry (PBI) Global responds to the need for research-informed and field-tested products with iterative development and implementation of a globally relevant, inquiry-based STEM curriculum. The project focuses on developing 9th grade student physical, biological, and environmental science content knowledge and science and engineering practices through the topics of global water and sanitation issues. Factors influencing student motivation and engagement, as well as teacher attitudes toward inquiry-based pedagogies will be investigated.  The project will use a Design-Based Research (DBR) approach to develop and refine instructional materials and teacher professional development for the existing interdisciplinary PBI Global initiative. A mixed-methods research convergent parallel design will be used to explore the effects of the classroom implementation on student and teacher outcomes.

The Discovery Research K-12 program (DRK-12) seeks to significantly enhance the learning and teaching of science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) by preK-12 students and teachers, through research and development of innovative resources, models and tools. Projects in the DRK-12 program build on fundamental research in STEM education and prior research and development efforts that provide theoretical and empirical justification for proposed projects.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Project-Based Inquiry (PBI) Global is a five-phase inquiry-to-action process that supports students in collaborating to ask compelling questions; gather and analyze sources; creatively synthesize claims and evidences; critically evaluate and revise; and share, publish, and act to address one or more of the most pressing challenges the world faces. For this three-year NSF DRK-12-funded project Supporting Students Science Content Knowledge through PBI Global, the PBI Global process was aligned with UN Sustainable Development Goal (SDG) 6: Clean Water and Adequate Sanitation. The researchers partnered with teachers and students at two cooperative innovative high schools in the southeastern United States to examine how inquiry-based learning through PBI Global relates to student motivation and science content knowledge, as well as how engagement in PBI Global impacts teacher and student attitudes toward inquiry-based teaching and learning. Additional outcomes from this project were the iterative design of interdisciplinary instructional materials for the PBI Global focused on SDG 6: Clean Water and Adequate Sanitation and PBI Global teacher professional development.

 

During Year 1 of this project (2019-2020), researchers, teachers, and students from two schools (one suburban and one rural) collaborated to complete PBI Global immediately prior to the closing of school buildings and shift to emergency remote learning due to COVID-19. Given the challenges facing schools, teachers, and students during the 2020-21 school year, the teachers at both schools opted to engage in separate PBI Globals, albeit remotely and in hybrid instructional contexts, during year 2 of the project. Although this shift from cross-school to separate PBI Globals was not intentional, it has supported each school in making PBI Global their own, adapting the framework to their unique school characteristics, personnel, and cultures. One of the partner schools has integrated a social action component into all of their interdisciplinary school projects as a result of their PBI Global experiences, while the other school is pursuing an SDG 6-focused PBI Global collaboration with a school in China for the 2022-23 school year. As an interdisciplinary instructional framework, PBI Global?s emphasis on inquiry-to-action affords teachers and students with opportunities to examine issues of local and global significance and to take steps toward addressing these challenges on local and global scales.

 

Results from the first year of the project showed increases in students? motivation and engagement after participating in PBI Global. Student focus group findings highlighted that over the project students: (1) constructed empathy for working with diverse groups and for global challenges, (2) found relevance of the instructional content and value in the stages of the PBI Global process, and (3) navigated challenges of collaborating with a school in a separate area of the state. Results from the second year of the project showed that students were more confident in their knowledge of water and sanitation after participating in the project and that they had an increase in empowerment after engaging in PBI Global. In focus groups, students noted feeling motivated to share their ideas and to learn STEM content to solve global problems.
